questions.text: On the initial day of treatment for a child diagnosed with Severe Acute Malnutrition, the attending physician calculates the dose of folic acid to administer. What is the standard initial dosage of folic acid for a child on the first day of SAM management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 5 mg

 

Explanation:

 

The recommended initial dose of folic acid in the management of SAM is 5 mg on the first day and then 1 mg every day till day 14 of treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Management of SAM - Micronutrients supplementation

 

  • Use up to twice the recommended daily allowance of various vitamins and minerals.

  • On day 1, give vitamin A orally (if age >1 yr give 2 lakh IU; age 6-12 mo give 1 lakh IU; age 0-5 mo give 50,000 IU)

  • Folic acid 1 mg/ day (give 5 mg on day 1)

  • Zinc 2 mg/kg/ day

  • Copper 0.2-0.3 mg/kg/day

  • Iron 3 mg/ kg/ day, once child starts gaining weight; after the stabilization phase.

 

Ref: Op Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 93.

choices.text: A1 B2 C3 D4
A4 B3 C2 D1
A3 B4 C2 D1
A2 B3 C1 D4

questions.text:
Identify the following instruments which are used for the measurement of the nutritional status of the child?

 

 

1. Harpenden caliper

2. Salters Scale

3. Shakir’s Tape

4. Infantometer
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A3 B4 C2 D1

 

Option C:

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Tape Measure: Used for measuring mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC), which is an important anthropometric measurement of nutritional status, particularly in identifying malnutrition in children.

 

Option B. Infantometer: This device is used to measure the length or height of infants and small children. It is essential for assessing linear growth and determining stunting.

 

Option C. Spring Scale: Often used for weighing infants and young children. The child is usually placed in a sling which is then attached to the scale.

 

Option D. Skinfold Caliper: Utilized to measure skinfold thickness at various body sites to estimate body fat percentage, a key component in evaluating nutritional status.

 

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition page number 1842

choices.text: Weight for height of the child.
Weight for age of the child.

questions.text: In the outpatient department, a concerned mother presents with her baby, Anu, who hails from a region currently experiencing severe drought conditions. Upon examination, Anu appears severely malnourished, prompting an urgent need for nutritional assessment. To determine the extent of acute malnutrition in Anu, which of the following parameters would be most appropriate for evaluation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Weight for height of the child.

 

Option B:

 

The most accurate parameter for assessing acute malnutrition is Weight for Height. This measurement reflects the current nutritional status and is used to identify wasting, which indicates acute malnutrition. It shows whether the child's weight is appropriate for their height, irrespective of their age, making it a critical indicator for immediate nutritional interventions.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Height for Age: This parameter is used to assess stunting, which indicates chronic malnutrition. It reflects the long-term nutritional and health status of the child and is not the best indicator for acute malnutrition.

 

Option C. Weight for Age: This combines both acute and chronic aspects of malnutrition, making it less specific for acute malnutrition. It can indicate underweight status but doesn't distinguish between stunting (chronic malnutrition) and wasting (acute malnutrition).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute malnutrition is also known as wasting & the parameter affected is weight for height

 

Ref- Op Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 93.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to your clinic with concerns about inadequate growth and development. The mother describes her child's appetite as poor, with frequent episodes of diarrhea. Upon examination, you note that the child's weight falls below the 3rd percentile for their age, and their weight-for-height is at 80% of the expected value. Additionally, the child's height is also below the 3rd percentile for their age group. Based on this clinical presentation, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stunting

 

Option B:

 

Stunting is characterized by low height for age and is an indicator of chronic malnutrition, reflecting a prolonged period of inadequate nutrition, which might include both macronutrient and micronutrient deficiencies, as well as frequent infections like diarrhea. The child's height being below the 3rd percentile for age, despite poor weight, suggests that the growth retardation has been a long-term issue, pointing towards stunting as the most likely diagnosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Acute malnutrition: Typically indicated by wasting (low weight for height), acute malnutrition reflects recent and severe deprivation of food rather than long-term nutritional status, which seems less likely given the chronic presentation.

 

Option C. Wasting: Characterized by low weight for height, wasting indicates acute malnutrition. Although the child's weight for height is low (80% of the expected value), the concurrent height deficit suggests a chronic condition, making stunting more likely. Low weight for age suggests underweight.

 

Option D. Obesity: This is characterized by excess body fat and a high BMI for age and is clearly not consistent with the child's presentation of being underweight and having stunted growth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stunting, as the child is below the 3rd percentile for height for age, indicating chronic malnutrition.

 

Ref- Op Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 93.

questions.text: During your community medicine rotation in a rural setting, you engage in discussions with the local medical officer about the assessment of malnutrition in children. After reviewing various parameters used to diagnose malnutrition, the medical officer poses a question about which indicator can be used independently of a child's age. Which of the following would you identify as an age-independent indicator of malnutrition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) MUAC

 

Option D:

 

Mid-Upper Arm Circumference (MAC) is an age-independent indicator of malnutrition. MAC is used to assess nutritional status by measuring the circumference of the left upper arm, midway between the tip of the shoulder and the tip of the elbow. This measurement reflects muscle and fat stores and is particularly useful in settings where age information may be unreliable or unknown. It's a quick, simple, and effective tool for identifying malnutrition, especially in community settings or during mass screenings.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Underweight: Being underweight is a condition where a child's weight is significantly lower than the average for their age and gender. It is age dependent as it requires comparison to standard growth charts that consider age.

 

Option B. Stunting: Stunting is defined as a low height for age and is a sign of chronic malnutrition. It indicates that a child has not grown as expected due to long-term nutritional deprivation, illness, or poor social conditions. This is also age dependent as it involves comparing a child's height to standard growth charts based on age.

 

Option C. Wasting: Wasting is a condition where a child has a low weight for their height, indicating acute malnutrition. Wasting is age-dependent because it requires the comparison of a child's weight and height against age-based growth standards.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mid arm circumference is age independent indicator of malnutrition.

 

 

Ref- Op Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 93.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to your clinic displaying symptoms of edema, irritability, and distinctive skin lesions. The mother describes the child's diet as being predominantly high in carbohydrates with a significant lack of protein. Laboratory findings reveal hypoalbuminemia and anemia. Based on the clinical presentation and the dietary history, what is the most probable diagnosis for this child's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Kwashiorkor.

 

Option B:

 

Kwashiorkor is the most likely diagnosis in this case based on the clinical presentation and laboratory findings.

 

Kwashiorkor is a form of protein-energy malnutrition that results from an inadequate protein intake but with adequate calorie intake. It is characterized by edema, irritability, skin lesions, and a swollen liver. Laboratory studies may show hypoalbuminemia and anemia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Marasmus is a severe form of protein-energy malnutrition that results from prolonged inadequate intake of both calories and protein. It is characterized by severe wasting and malnutrition, loss of subcutaneous fat and muscle mass, and lethargy.

 

Option C. Rickets is a disease that occurs due to a deficiency of vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate. It causes softening and weakening of the bones in children and can lead to fractures and deformities.

 

Option D. Scurvy is a disease that occurs due to a deficiency of vitamin C. It causes fatigue, muscle weakness, joint and muscle aches, and bleeding gums.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kwashiorkor is a protein-energy malnutrition disorder characterized by edema, irritability, skin lesions, hypoalbuminemia, and anemia, largely due to a diet deficient in protein but adequate in calories.

 

Ref- Op Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 95-97.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the emergency department with a 3-day history of persistent diarrhea and vomiting. The mother mentions that the child has had a significantly reduced intake of food and fluids during this period. Clinical examination reveals that the child's weight is below 70% of the expected value for their age, while their height remains within the normal range for age. Based on the presenting symptoms and clinical findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute malnutrition

 

Option A:

 

The child's weight is below 70% of the expected value for age, which indicates that the child is suffering from acute malnutrition. Acute malnutrition is characterized by rapid weight loss and wasting, which occurs due to a lack of food or nutrients during a short period. In addition, the child's height for age is normal, indicating that the child has not suffered from chronic malnutrition, which results in stunting. Therefore, the correct answer is A. Acute malnutrition.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Stunting: This option is incorrect because the child's height for age is normal, indicating the absence of chronic malnutrition.

 

Option C. Chronic malnutrition is also known as stunting and the parameter affected is height for age.

 

Option D. Obesity: This option is incorrect because the child's weight is below the expected value for age, indicating malnutrition, rather than obesity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute malnutrition indeed encompasses a broader category of nutritional deficiencies, including wasting, and is characterized by a rapid decline in weight due to inadequate nutrient intake or illness, such as the diarrhea and vomiting described in the child's case.

 

Ref- Op Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 93.

questions.text: A 9-month-old infant is brought to a pediatric clinic, exhibiting signs of severe wasting, lethargy, pronounced loss of subcutaneous fat, and muscle mass depletion. Laboratory investigations reveal deficiencies in essential vitamins and minerals. Based on the clinical presentation and laboratory findings, which of the following diagnoses is most consistent with the child's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Marasmus.

 

Option B:

 

Marasmus is the most likely diagnosis in this case based on the clinical presentation and laboratory findings.

 

Marasmus is a severe form of protein-energy malnutrition that results from prolonged inadequate intake of both calories and protein. It is characterized by severe wasting and malnutrition, loss of subcutaneous fat and muscle mass, and lethargy. Laboratory studies may show hypoalbuminemia and low levels of essential vitamins and minerals.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Kwashiorkor is another form of protein-energy malnutrition that results from an inadequate protein intake but with adequate calorie intake. It is characterized by edema, hepatomegaly, and skin lesions, but not wasting or loss of muscle mass.

 

Option C. Rickets is a disease that occurs due to a deficiency of vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate. It causes softening and weakening of the bones in children and can lead to fractures and deformities.

 

Option D. Scurvy is a disease that occurs due to a deficiency of vitamin C. It causes fatigue, muscle weakness, joint and muscle aches, and bleeding gums. It does not result in wasting or loss of muscle mass.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Marasmus â€“ Diagnosis characterized by severe caloric and protein deficiency leading to significant wasting and loss of muscle mass. Understanding these distinctions is crucial for pediatricians to provide appropriate care and nutritional interventions for affected children.

 

Ref- Op Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 95-97.

choices.text: First Day of Admission
20th Day of Admission

questions.text: A pediatrician is strategizing the nutritional rehabilitation plan for a child with Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM). Given the complexities associated with SAM, careful consideration is given to the timing of iron supplementation to avoid exacerbating the condition. At what point in the treatment of SAM is iron supplementation deemed appropriate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rehabilitation Phase

 

Option B:

 

Iron supplementation is introduced during the Rehabilitation Phase of SAM treatment to avoid potential adverse effects such as oxidative stress and increased susceptibility to infections that can occur if given during the initial, more critical Stabilization Phase.

 

The general treatment involves ten steps in two phases:

 

  • The initial stabilization phase focuses on restoring homeostasis and treating medical complications and usually takes 2-7 days of inpatient treatment.
  • The rehabilitation phase focuses on rebuilding wasted tissues and may take several week

 

The time frame for Management of Severe Malnutrition in 10 steps

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: In the Stabilization Phase, the focus is on managing acute complications and stabilizing the child's condition; iron could exacerbate infections.

 

Option C & Option D: Specifying exact days (First Day or 20th Day) is less relevant than understanding the phase of treatment. Iron is not typically started based on the day of admission but rather the child's clinical progress and phase of treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron in SAM is not given in the stabilization phase as it can lead to free radical generation and bacterial fermentation. The appropriate timing for iron supplementation in SAM treatment, is Rehabilitation Phase.

 

Ref: Op Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 93.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents to the clinic for a routine check-up. The child's mother reports that the child has been losing weight and has a poor appetite for the past few months. The child has also been suffering from recurrent infections. On examination, the child's weight for height is below the 70% of the expected value, and the child's height for age is normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Wasting

 

As the child's weight for height is below the 70% of the expected value, indicating wasting.

 

The child's weight for height is below the 70% of the expected value, indicating that the child is suffering from wasting, a form of malnutrition characterized by rapid weight loss and muscle wasting. However, the child's height for age is normal, indicating the absence of chronic malnutrition or stunting. Recurrent infections and poor appetite can contribute to the development of wasting. Therefore, the correct answer is C. Wasting.

 

Option A. Chronic malnutrition - Chronic malnutrition is not present in this case because for chronic malnutrition the parameter affected is height for age

 

Option B. Stunting - Stunting is not present in this case, as the child's height for age is normal.

 

Option D. Obesity - This option is incorrect because the child's weight for height is below the 70% of the expected value, indicating malnutrition, rather than obesity.

 

Ref- Op Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 93.

choices.text: Mid arm circumference in 0-1year age group
Anemia detection in pregnancy
Height and weight calculated in < 5years age group

questions.text: While working in a primary healthcare (PHC) setting, you are tasked with assessing the nutritional status of the local community. You consider several parameters to evaluate the community's nutritional health. Which of the following parameters is NOT typically used to measure the nutritional status of a community?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mid arm circumference in 0-1year age group.

 

Option A:

 

Mid-arm circumference (MAC) is a useful indicator for assessing malnutrition in individual children, especially between the ages of 6 months and 5 years. However, as a community-wide indicator, it is not typically used alone to assess the overall nutritional status of the community. MAC is particularly valuable in settings where it is difficult to obtain accurate ages of children or to perform more comprehensive nutritional assessments.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Anemia detection in pregnancy: This is a common indicator used to assess the nutritional status of a community because anemia in pregnancy can indicate poor nutritional status among women of childbearing age and can have implications for the health of the community.

 

Option C. Childbirth weight < 2500 grams: Low birth weight is a significant indicator of the community's nutritional status as it reflects maternal health and nutrition during pregnancy, as well as the health and nutrition of the newborn.

 

Option D. Height and weight measured in children under 5 years of age: These are fundamental parameters for determining the prevalence of stunting and wasting, which are key indicators of chronic and acute malnutrition in a community.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MAC is assessed in 1- 5year age group

 

Ref- Op Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 93.

questions.text: In managing a 13-month with SAM who weighs 7 kg, a medical officer prepares to administer Vitamin A as part of the comprehensive treatment plan. What is the correct dosage of Vitamin A for this infant?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 100,000 IU

 

Explanation:

 

Vitamin A dose

 

<6 months: 50,000 IU

 

6-12 months: 1 lakh IU

 

>12 months: 2 Lakh IU

 

If the baby is >12 months & <8kg: 1 lakh IU

 

Educational Objective:

 

Management of SAM - Micronutrients supplementation

 

  • Use up to twice the recommended daily allowance of various vitamins and minerals

  • On day 1, give vitamin A orally (if age >1 yr give 2 lakh IU; age 6-12 mo give 1 lakh IU; age 0-5 mo give 50,000 IU)

  • Folic acid 1 mg/ day (give 5 mg on day 1)

  • Zinc 2 mg/kg/ day

  • Copper 0.2-0.3 mg/kg/day

  • Iron 3 mg/ kg/ day, once child starts gaining weight; after the stabilization phase

 

Ref: Op Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 93.

choices.text: None of the Above

questions.text: A community health worker evaluating children in a rural health clinic uses specific anthropometric measurements to assess nutritional status. Which measurement is primarily used to diagnose chronic malnutrition, indicating long-term nutritional deficits?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Height for Age

 

Option B:

 

Height for Age is the key anthropometric indicator for assessing chronic malnutrition or stunting, reflecting long-term inadequate nutrition or repeated bouts of illness affecting growth.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Weight for Height is used to assess acute malnutrition or wasting.

 

Option C: Weight for Age can indicate both acute and chronic malnutrition but is less specific than Height for Age for chronic conditions.

 

Option D: One of the listed measurements is indeed used to diagnose chronic malnutrition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Height for Age is the primary indicator of chronic malnutrition.

 

Ref: Op Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 95

choices.text: Hb 4-6 g/dL with features of distress
None of the Above

questions.text: A child with Severe Acute Malnutrition presents with anemia, and the treating physician considers a blood transfusion. Under which conditions is a blood transfusion indicated in the management of SAM?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A+B is Correct

 

Option D:

 

If a severely malnourished child has severe anemia with a hemoglobin less than 4 g/ dl or between 4 and 6 g/dl but with respiratory distress, a blood transfusion should be given with whole blood 10 ml/kg bodyweight slowly over 3 hr.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The criteria for blood transfusion in children with SAM –

 

  • In mild to moderate anemia, iron should be given for two months to replete iron stores but this should not be started until after the initial stabilization phase has been completed.
  • Hb level between 4-6 g/dL when accompanied by clinical features of distress and below 4 g/dL – is an indication of BT

 

Ref: Op Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 93.

choices.text: Quaker Arm Circumference and Jelliffe Ratio
All of the Above

questions.text: In a training session for healthcare workers focusing on nutritional assessments in low-resource settings, the facilitator discusses various methods for diagnosing severe acute malnutrition (SAM) that do not rely on the age of the child. Which of these indices are recognized for their age-independent utility in assessing and diagnosing SAM?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the Above

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Kanawati and McLaren: This method involves using anthropometric measurements that don't necessarily depend on the child's age, making it suitable for evaluating nutritional status in diverse settings.

 

Option B. Rao and Singh: This index, like the others mentioned, provides a way to assess nutritional status without directly involving the child's age, focusing instead on measurements that can indicate malnutrition.

 

Option C. Quaker Arm Circumference and Jelliffe Ratio: The Jelliffe Ratio is another metric used in nutritional assessments that does not depend on knowing the child's exact age.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kanawati and McLaren, Rao and Singh, and Quaker Arm Circumference (often referred to as MUAC) along with the Jelliffe Ratio, are considered age-independent indices in the context of diagnosing SAM. These methods provide valuable metrics for assessing nutritional status without relying on the age of the child, which can be particularly useful in settings where accurate age information might not be readily available.

 

Ref: Op Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 94

questions.text: In managing a child with Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM), a pediatrician reviews the common complications that can arise and significantly impact the treatment approach. A well-recognized triad of complications is particularly critical for immediate recognition and management. Which of the following represents this crucial triad in SAM?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypoglycemia + Hypothermia + Infection

 

Option A:

 

In SAM, the triad of hypoglycemia, hypothermia, and infection constitutes a critical set of complications that require prompt identification and treatment. Hypoglycemia and hypothermia reflect the body's depleted energy reserves and impaired thermoregulation, while infection indicates the compromised immune status common in malnutrition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The triad of hypoglycemia, hypothermia, and infection as key complications in children with Severe Acute Malnutrition, highlighting the importance of vigilant monitoring and prompt intervention in the management of these patients.

 

Ref: Op Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 93.

questions.text: A nurse is preparing to administer a corrective treatment for asymptomatic hypoglycemia in a child with Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM). According to the standard protocol, what volume of 10% dextrose should be given orally or through a nasogastric tube to effectively manage this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 50 mL

 

Option D:

 

For the correction of asymptomatic hypoglycemia in a child with SAM, the administration of 50 mL of 10% dextrose is recommended. This dosage helps to quickly elevate blood glucose levels, providing a rapid source of energy to the child.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Management of Hypoglycemia in SAM –

 

Treatment

 

  • Asymptomatic hypoglycemia - Give 50 ml of 10% glucose or sucrose solution orally or by nasogastric tube followed by first feed. Feed with starter F-75 every 2 hourly day and night
  • Symptomatic hypoglycemia - Give 10% dextrose IV 5 ml/kg. Follow with 50 ml of 10% dextrose or sucrose solution by nasogastric tube. Feed with starter F-75 every 2 hourly day and night. Start appropriate antibiotics.

 

Prevention

 

  • Feed 2 hourly starting immediately
  • Prevent hypothermia

 

Ref- Op Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 93.

choices.text: 0.9 gram protein + 2.6 gram lactose
1.9 gram protein + 1.8 gram lactose
2.9 gram protein + 4.8 gram lactose
0.9 gram protein + 1.2 gram lactose

questions.text: In a workshop on nutritional rehabilitation for children with severe acute malnutrition (SAM), a dietitian discusses the composition of therapeutic milk formulas used during the initial stabilization phase. F-75 therapeutic milk is designed to provide essential nutrients without overburdening the child's compromised metabolism. What are the correct amounts of protein and lactose per 100 mL in the F-75 formula?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 0.9 gram protein + 1.2 gram lactose

 

Option D:

 

F-75 therapeutic milk, tailored for the stabilization phase of SAM treatment, contains 0.9 grams of protein and 1.2 grams of lactose per 100 mL. This careful balance is intended to meet the child's nutritional needs without imposing a heavy metabolic burden.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Starter Diet

 

 

Ref- Op Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 93.

questions.text: During a nutrition support team meeting, a dietitian highlights the critical importance of monitoring for refeeding syndrome in patients who are starting nutritional rehabilitation after a period of starvation or severe malnutrition. She outlines the classical triad of electrolyte imbalances that characterize refeeding syndrome, which must be vigilantly managed to prevent complications. What constitutes this triad?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypokalemia, Hypomagnesemia, Hypophosphatemia

 

Option A:

 

Refeeding syndrome is characterized by the triad of hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, and hypophosphatemia. These electrolyte imbalances occur when nutritional support is initiated in malnourished patients, leading to a sudden shift in electrolytes and fluids within the body.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Hypothermia is not part of the classic triad of refeeding syndrome, which focuses on electrolyte disturbances.

 

Option C: Hypoglycemia is a concern in malnutrition but not typically part of the refeeding syndrome triad, which involves shifts in electrolytes due to insulin secretion and cellular uptake of glucose.

 

Option D: Bradycardia is a potential clinical manifestation in severe cases but not a defining component of the refeeding syndrome triad.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The key electrolyte disturbances associated with refeeding syndrome: hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, and hypophosphatemia. Recognizing and managing these imbalances is crucial in the nutritional rehabilitation of severely malnourished patients to prevent the complications associated with refeeding syndrome.

 

Ref- Op Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 93.

choices.text: Weight for Height reaches -2 SD or higher
Weight for Height reaches -3 SD or higher
Weight for Age reaches -2SD or higher
Height for Age reaches -2 SD or higher

questions.text: A pediatric nutritionist is discussing the discharge criteria for children admitted with Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) at a regional health conference. She emphasizes the importance of ensuring that children have reached a certain threshold of recovery before they are discharged to continue outpatient care. According to international guidelines, a child with SAM is considered fit for discharge when which nutritional status indicator reaches a specific threshold?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Weight for Height reaches -2 SD or higher

 

Option A:

 

For a child with SAM to be considered fit for discharge, their Weight for Height (WFH) ratio should reach -2 standard deviations (SD) or higher from the median of the World Health Organization (WHO) growth standards. This indicates significant nutritional recovery and reduced risk of morbidity and mortality associated with acute malnutrition

 

Educational Objective:

 

The readiness for discharge of a child with SAM from a hospital setting involves a multifaceted assessment that includes –

 

  • Nutritional recovery (such as reaching 90% of the NCHS median for Weight for Height or achieving a 15% weight gain without edema),
  • Clinical signs (the child being alert and active with consistent weight gain on exclusive oral feeding and free from infection),
  • Completion of necessary medical treatments and immunizations, and
  • Ensuring that the caregiver is fully prepared for home care, including the ability to provide appropriate feeding and follow-up care.

 

For some children, earlier discharge might be considered if they are older than 12 months, showing good progress, and if there is a reliable plan for continued care and supervision at home.

 

Ref- Op Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 93.

choices.text: Both can have mortality
Mortality in both cases will be less

questions.text:
A pediatric resident is presented with two contrasting cases of pediatric patients during their rotation. The resident is asked to assess which case would generally be associated with a higher risk of mortality without intervention.

 

 

Based on the clinical presentation, which child would typically be at a higher risk of mortality?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fatty Baby


Option B:

 

Kwashiorkor is associated with a higher immediate risk of mortality compared to marasmus. This is due to its complex metabolic disturbances, vulnerability to infections, and potential complications from edema affecting vital organs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Differences between kwashiorkor and marasmus

 

 

Ref- Op Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 93.
